We omit here various execrations with
which these honest gentlemen garnished
their discourse, retaining only such of their
expletives as are least offensive.
"'A does not mid wind and weather -
'A has had many a north-easter in his day.''
"He had his last yesterday," said an-
other gruffly, "and now old Meg may pray
for his last fair wind as she's. often done
before.''
"I'll pray for nane o' him,." said Meg,
"nor for you neither, you randy dog.
The times are sair altered since I was a
kinchin-mort. Men were men then, and
fought other in the open field, and there
was nale milling in the darkmans. And
the gentry had kind hearts; and would
have given both lap and pannel to ony
poor gypsy; and there: was not one, from
